comments.commentBody: Don't hold your breath, er, bladder...
Maybe this will spur the Kraft family to re-consider moving the Revs closer to Boston.
Circumstance, not cleverness, has always been the prescription for access.
This must be the most poorly orchestrated, worst-concealed scandal ever. If the economic elite is going to manipulate things to their advantage, I expect them to at least be a little clever about it.
Call it the "Game's over, put away your pieces" tax.

Anon, the “death tax” as Republicans like to call it is a tax on the very, very, rich. Only the top 3/10 of 1 percent pay estate taxes. Teddy Roosevelt did not think that it was right that a small number of people could have a huge concentration of wealth. Thus, leading to an oligarchy.
The inheritance tax was very hard on small business owners who didn't have tax savvy.

Many of the ultra rich came to money through inheritance.  The recipients did nothing to deserve or earn their wealth. A healthy inheritance tax is the only barrier to a permanent aristocracy.  We must allow the changes to the inheritance tax to expire when the rest of the Bush tax cuts expire.

Rumor has it that pre-Columbian American societies thought they would fall apart unless from time to time a virgin was taken to the top of the volcano and thrown in. We laugh at these societies and call them "primitive".

Cutting taxes on the super-rich won't help the economy in the Krugman/Adam Smith tradition: it is our version of sacrifice that will keep an unknowable Economic God happy. Other societies have added to financial incentives cutesy titles like Duke and Baron (Mitt Romney, Count of Massachusetts, Baron of the Hamptons, Lord of the Garage Elevator). Scholars think the story is bunk, but Mozart wrote a very popular opera based on the idea we let medieval Job Creators sleep with our newly-wed wives as a reward for their munificence.

Probably the economy would be served best by throwing a virgin of our own into a volcano, if he have any volcanoes or virgins left.

The super-rich don't really care what happens to the US. They don't really live here, or anywhere for that matter. They believe their wealth will always find a home in a beautiful gated waterfront community somewhere in the world --California, Costa Rica, Aruba, Singapore-- really, any port will do. Locale loyalty does not exist.

The US simply represents the best opportunity for profit. When it's over, they will simply take the money and run elsewhere. Home is where the cash is.
One of the problems is that even the current administration has tax-dodgers in it and it didn't seem to disqualify them from office.
You don't get it, do you?  They like third world countries where the few have all the money and everyone else is dirt poor.  They dream of having that here!  That has been their goal since Reagan.

I second Charles. WHY is anyone but the superrich voting for Romney. It is mystifying.

Why is anyone moral voiting for Romney. Tax-dodger and Tax-cheat used to be enough to disqualify people from decent society, let alone running for office. What happened?

And, why are the super rich voting for Romney. This wealth inequality will make the nation about as economically vibrant as a second-rate Latin American banana republic of old. It will trash opportunity for the super rich along with everyone else! If the people do not do well, the rich will not do well -- sometimes with personal pain far beyond simply a dip in their bank accounts. Societies either adjust to pressures of inequality or they explode. We are on our way to an explosion.
Note to Matt: Krugman was being sarcastic when he calls the super rich job creators. If only the super rich really created jobs with the windfall they make for tax breaks instead of hoarding it.
In perfect world.  But free-market capitalism will never have anything close.  It's impossible.
You're not stupid, probably just naive. You also probably have a well developed sense of fairness and social justice. You are a great American. We need more of this....

I must just be stupid, but I don't understand why the "job creators," a.k.a. employers, deserve more laurels than those they hire. In a free-market system (which we generally have despite claims to the contrary), an employer does not hire someone out of the goodness of his or her heart, but rather if he or she thinks that the prospective employee's contributions will exceed the employee's compensation. Thus congratulations for a new hire should go to both the employee, who created (or inherited) his value, and the employer, who was wise enough to take advantage of that value.
The wealthy need the poor. The poor do not need the wealthy.

Yes, we have all been to functions where the food and slide projectors are just "there." Only when you have worked in event planning do you realize the amount of both highly organized coordination and highly muscled grunt work goes into preparing the environment. For the highly placed executive, it is a matter of just ordering it done and the rest of us make it happen.
I have always thought that the least enjoyable jobs should be most highly compensated.

I was at a satellite technology conference not long ago. It was the last hours of the last day in the exhibit hall, and the expensive suits were mingling with the jeans and t-shirt crowd coming to tear things down and move 'em out. I realized at that moment that none of the wheeling and dealing, none of the multimillion dollar deals being discussed and agreed up could be taking place without the workers who put the whole show in place. Nor, for that matter, without the underpaid people who brought in food, swept the floors, fixed the air conditioning, checked the badges. These are VIPs, too.

Who says that one man sitting at a desk is worth 500 times the guy who makes it possible for the desk to rest safely on the 59th floor? The rules and the laws have been written to benefit those who hold power and to leave those without it at the bottom of the economic pile. That's the way it is.

Now, a completely egalitarian economic division is probably impossible. So, too, is one that distributes so well that there is no poverty. Yet, America once achieved a truly remarkable distribution, mainly through wages, where most people's needs were met and the rich were merely rich, not super rich. Had we continued on that course, we would have a more balanced, fair society.

The very rich are stealing more than their share of our national wealth. They are doing it by both legal and illegal means. The wage increases of the middle have been taken by the very wealthy.

http://terryreport.com
So we rely on someone from Thailand to suggest we adopt a Pol Pot, Khmer Rouge approach, sheeesh!
Check your math. Problem may be smaller than you think.

The USA population is about 300,000,000. The Mitt Base is 0.01% of this or 3,000,000. 3,000,000 is a lot to eliminate through violence. The funding of the resources and logistics to do so would have a significant negative impact on our economy.

We cannot outspend them.

They own the so called 4th Estate and the means of mass communication.

What to do? Seriously, what to do?

Republicans claim Democrats are trying to turn America into Europe.

Well, Republicans are turning us into Pakistan...
I think it's hilarious that NY Times readers consider themselves sophisticates while having no means to debate, save name-calling.

The Republican party is a runaway freight train of Know-Nothing, tax-dodging sociopaths who don't deserve a place at the political table.

If one doesn't recognize the fundamental need for adequately funding education, infrastructure, healthcare and regulating greedy sociopaths who repeatedly destroy global economic stability, then one has worn out their welcome as a member of decent society.

The Republican platform is a feudal, Dickensian recipe for third-worldism through financial starvation of government at the local, state and national level.

In short, the unpatriotic Republican fetish against taxes is sedition, plain and simple.

When Republicans wave the flag, they do so only to hypnotize their low-information voters who don't understand math, English or propaganda very well.
Hear! Hear! Well said. Agreed! As said by a much better man than me, Walt Kelly, "We've met the enemy and he is us."

I can think of plenty of people throughout history who were important yet loathsome. Value is based on the perceptions of others, not the object itself. Clearly this type of "VIP" has value to this craven version of the formerly GOP because they value their money and power. They Republican Party is already well on its way to being consumed by the devil it is courting. One can already see the wise in the GOP headed for the doors, like Senator Snowe.

However, its only when the majority of the American electorate decide to end its self-imposed "Stockholm syndrome" and see itself as "very important" (like our kids' possibility of a living wage, like the political independence of the judiciary, like access to health care, like freedom from incessant political fundraising and a return to true philanthropy to name a few "important" examples) that we can pop the over-inflated VIP bubbles such as those attending Mr. Romney's glad-handing festival in the Hamptons.

Just like any other economic bubble, futures on VIPs are inflated. The wiser party will divest and invest in the majority.

Belief is a powerful thing.

You can believe the world is flat and until a major paradigm shift unseats your belief there is nothing in the rising and setting of the sun to convince you otherwise.

And therefore you can vote for Mitt Romney and you can make the Congress Republican.

Dear Dr. Krugman,

If only your fellow-economists had your courage and conviction to declare to the country that tax cuts for the upper 0.01 percent are not going to solve the jobs crisis, anymore than praying to the rain god produces rain. Without such support, I am afraid the lay public will remain ignorant and the republicans will get away with their agenda of cutting taxes for their true constituency, the rich, and trashing the country in the process. The 0.01 percent have already bought the supreme court and the congress (both houses) and are now aiming for the third branch. Heaven help us if president Obama loses and there is no one to veto their (I do mean their) bills passed through a pliant congress selected and elected by them! That will be the end of a magnificent experiment in history of a government of the people, by the people and for the people!

What passes for capitalism in these circles seems to be buying and selling businesses rather than starting them. Romney may have helped finance some start ups, but he really has no idea how to produce anything. His buying and selling followed a formula which tend to disadvantage slow growing, longstanding businesses. They were hollowed out, soutsourced and often crippled in terms of serving their historic markets. It didn't matter to him or his colleagues beyond finding some suckers to buy these businesses they had restructured. I spent a number of years in Atlanta, where the dream of many people was sort of like this--buying and selling, producing nothing very useful. No one ever came out and said it, but it was a suckers' game. It created a place that was full of glitz based on credit card debt and a society that had a lot of half-developed cultural institutions, unsustainable sprawl, very little real wealth, weak civil societyand a vapid consumer culture, as well as a lack of charity beyond churches. I think that's the kind of America the VIPs want for the rest of us. Interestingly, Atlanta's housing market, a big part of its suckers' culture has fallen further, though more gradually than Miami's or LA's, with no real bottom, yet. The suckers' game can't sustain even in a natural home like Atlanta.

Stephen, I fear the good professor is correct, as he has been in every instance since 2008.
Never in our history have we been cursed with an electorate as ignorant, uneducated, fearful, angry and resentful of their neighbors as now.
Is there room in your country for one more disillusioned American? One who doesn't object to paying taxes when he knows that's the price for a fair and functional society?

Jumper:

"If the wealthy elite prevail, the rest of us will exist deprived of hope for upward mobility in a police state protecting the wealthy elite."

And we're seeing how that eventually plays out: cf the Arab Spring.
Jumper is wrong. We are past the end of the beginning. We are on the downslope.

What kind of world is this?  "...the wealthy are suspect and must be carefully supervised."  So, we go to report the activities of your neighbor to the authorities world.  I seem to have heard of that approach before....Nazi Germany, China, any others?

We're watching the beginning of the end of the innocence of our democracy. The innocence has been the school house mantra that we all work together, in our different ways, for the wide-spread prosperity of our nation. Or, we all work together to enjoy. a high standard of living.

Instead of sharing the prosperity of our huge national increase in productivity, those with the wealth to do so bought elected representatives to pass tax laws that advantaged them, and with propaganda, lied about benefits of cutting taxes, and fear mongered the public out of employment protections and into decreased wages, a million or more lost jobs, end of pensions, and near end of health insurance. As economic conflict arose, they blanketed the media with PR to marginalize as trouble-makers, or as naive, or as jealous, those who dared point out the program of class warfare.

When this is over, if the working and middle class prevail, we will have a national ethic that the wealthy are suspect and must be carefully supervised. If the wealthy elite prevail, the rest of us will exist deprived of hope for upward mobility in a police state protecting the wealthy elite.

I live in a poor town in a poor state. Both are solidly Republican. Here is why they vote the way they do.  The only thing they understand is that they don't like abortion and they do like a huge military. The reason they support a huge military is because that is the only option for many of their children. They don't understand that the rich pay no taxes. They don't understand that corporations are not looking out for their best interests. All they understand is abortion and military.Oh, and they are racist so they don't like the president. (I'm not making that up. All I hear around here are racist jokes about Obama and ranting over his needing "to accept Jesus Christ."

Never underestimate the power and skill of fascists to play the politics of envy and resentment: "Wouldn't you love to have what I have? Well, you - and our beloved nation/tribe - would be much farther along if those no-good, dead-beat [insert disfavored group, tribe, etc] weren't cutting in line ahead of you and unfairly rigging the system. I *deserve* what I've got, and you deserve more, too. So, I'm going to fight for you."

I'm not saying they're the only ones playing the envy-hero worship-resentment game, I'm saying that history shows the fascists/predators are the masters. And of course, a media that fawns over power and celebrity enables them.

Every religion is used by people to discriminate against others ! Hinduism is no exception !
Caste rears it's ugly head again !  The cruel things people can do to other humans in the name of God and Religion is absolutely shocking ! And, God 's response ? Muted silence !

"People in the West seeking sperms look for Tall, Blue-eyed Caucasian men" ???

You have obviously NEVER heard of something called High-IQ sperm banks which are exceedingly popular. So much so, as to get mentions in popular culture & TV sitcoms. Your ignorance is excusable on account of still wide gap in synapses of cultures, prejudiced as it and you may be..

Who knows. Commenting for the sake of it maybe?

Les Coherent & more disjointed with each comment, please organise your thoughts Mr. Mohanty and clarify which side of spectrum you hedge your bets on, left/right/which.

Used to be nicer earlier though, & better researched, worthy of an international forum.

Not necessarily, Narbal. Most people I know who have sought sperm (or egg) donations are looking for someone who physically resembles one of the partners in the relationship that is going to rear the child.

At issue here is the fallacy of 'blood purity' - the expression makes my skin crawl. It also runs contrary to just about all common sense, as even a cursory study of genetics reveals that another term for 'pure' bloodlines is 'inbreeding', with the corresponding proliferation of birth defects, and blood mixing produces what is called 'hybrid vigour'. Certainly the West has had a lot of experience with the delusion of 'blood purity' as desirable; however, at least some of us are, I hope, trying to move on.

Maybe, maybe not. If some kind of 'superiority', such as physical attractiveness or greater intelligence, is attached by popular belief to a higher caste, *and* movement between castes has historically been as common as you say, then it is certainly natural that lower-caste parents would want their child to be able to 'pass' by inheriting those traits. Perhaps the caste system has never been 'coherent' - in America and South Africa racial classifications have shown great flexibility and people have moved among them - but they did and do exist nonetheless.

What strikes me about the comments is how defensive Indians get to anything that even hints of less than 110% positive coverage of any aspect of India.
There might be a problem with this idea. What happens when all these fine young people encounter their half-brothers and sisters?
